normalised: The thing is, using pesticides is a bit of a double-edged sword. On one hand, you save your crop from those pesky insects, fungus, and weeds. Imagine a field of tomatoes getting completely wiped out by some bug – you’d be singing the blues all the way to Diwali! But on the other hand, overuse is a major problem. Professor Sharma at the Indian Agricultural Research Institute (I I R I) in Delhi has been saying this for years: too much pesticide ends up in the water, in the soil, and even in the food we eat.

normalised: I remember hearing about this farmer in Maharashtra, back in two thousand and ten, who sprayed so much pesticide that he accidentally poisoned himself. Scary stuff! That’s why everyone's talking about integrated pest management (I P M). Basically, it’s all about using pesticides smartly – only when absolutely necessary, and choosing the less harmful options. Things like neem oil sprays can work wonders, you know, if you catch the problem early enough. My nani used to swear by it!
